newsitem.title: GERMANY: German wheat withstands price pressure, sellers up.
newsitem.headline: German wheat withstands price pressure, sellers up.

text.p: German old and new crop wheat is offered quietly steadier, although rains across Europe have exerted downward pressure on prices, brokers said on Wednesday.
"Sellers are reluctant and European milling industries will need to replace more local wheat with German origin because of anticipated harvest losses," one said.
"This combination is boosting the price despite the current demand lull."
Prices in Britain, Spain, Portugal and some parts of France have fallen because of the weather.
Global prices are still high and the European Union decision to tax wheat exports -- while adding to worldwide tightness -- is calming the internal market.
Brokers said this would eventually reduce local prices.
Old crop barley and rye volumes were very scarce because they had been largely sold to feed manufacturers and intervention stores, brokers said.
New crop wheat negotiations had not started because initial levels were in a high 285-307.50 marks/tonne range, fob Baltic.
The Hamburg grain exchange this week raised its spot bread wheat price (12.5 percent, 220 Hagberg) by 2.50 marks to 287.50 marks a tonne free Hamburg.
But it left the spot feed wheat price unchanged at 280.
Fob Baltic sellers raised nominal first half May delivery wheat by between 1.00 and 2.50 marks versus April delivery but this reflected implied holding costs.
They quoted 12 percent protein wheat at 287.50-302.50 marks and 13/14 percent protein at 293.50-321 marks.
Limited fob Baltic barley offers were unchanged at 273.50 marks spot while rye sellers were at 270-275.
New crop wheat fob Baltic was offered in a 286-307.50 marks range and fob Rostock at 292.50-315, depending on dates, quality and shipment sizes.
